description: Microsoft Exchange 2013 is one of the most popular commercially supported email and collaboration platforms in the world. This course helps systems administrators to quickly come up to speed on deploying and supporting each of the various services provided in Exchange. In addition to the real world skills, this course also covers each of the exam objectives required for the Microsoft 70-341 exam which counts toward the MCP and MCSE certifications.
name: Microsoft Exchange 2013 - 70-341
subtitle: Core Solutions of Microsoft Exchange Server 2013

episodes.description: Microsoft Exchange 2013 is one of the most popular commercially supports email and collaboration platforms in the world. This course helps systems administrators to quickly come up to speed on deploying and supporting each of the various services provided in Exchange. In addition to the real world skills, this course also covers each of the exam objectives required for the Microsoft 70-341 exam which counts toward the MCP and MCSE certifications.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:05.186
[SOUND] In this series, we're gonna be

2
00:00:05.186 --> 00:00:11.646
taking a look at Microsoft Exchange 2013.

3
00:00:11.646 --> 00:00:14.872
We've had a lot of request from viewers
out there from people implementing their

4
00:00:14.872 --> 00:00:17.400
own email systems and
they're choosing Microsoft Exchange.

5
00:00:17.400 --> 00:00:18.410
They want some help to be able to do that.

6
00:00:18.410 --> 00:00:20.640
So that's what this series
is kinda built around.

7
00:00:20.640 --> 00:00:25.030
Now we're using the exam objectives for
the 70-341 exam to

8
00:00:25.030 --> 00:00:28.410
build this episode series, just to
make sure we cover all that content.

9
00:00:28.410 --> 00:00:31.140
Because it really is a great way
to get introduced to the product,

10
00:00:31.140 --> 00:00:34.140
as well as to get it implemented
quickly and reliably.

11
00:00:34.140 --> 00:00:38.140
Now that means that we're gonna cover a
lot of great stuff to get you exam ready,

12
00:00:38.140 --> 00:00:40.690
but from a practical sense
what are we gonna cover?

13
00:00:40.690 --> 00:00:44.910
Well, in this series we're going to take a
look at how to select the right edition of

14
00:00:44.910 --> 00:00:49.050
Microsoft Exchange, how to get Exchange
installed and have the right amount of

15
00:00:49.050 --> 00:00:53.060
servers for your environment, get that
network design properly put in place.

16
00:00:53.060 --> 00:00:56.944
How to implement mailbox services, which
is probably the most important part of

17
00:00:56.944 --> 00:00:58.890
an email server is to
be able to send email.

18
00:00:58.890 --> 00:01:01.140
But also take a look
at the calendaring and

19
00:01:01.140 --> 00:01:03.460
other functionality that's
built inside of Exchange.

20
00:01:03.460 --> 00:01:06.660
There is a ton of power under
the hood of Exchange that makes it

21
00:01:06.660 --> 00:01:08.560
far more than an email server.

22
00:01:08.560 --> 00:01:10.660
And we're gonna take a look
at all of that, right.

23
00:01:10.660 --> 00:01:12.790
Let's take a look at the exam
objectives to get a look at some of

24
00:01:12.790 --> 00:01:14.080
the things we're gonna cover.

25
00:01:14.080 --> 00:01:17.690
I said we were gonna build this
around the 70-341 exam and

26
00:01:17.690 --> 00:01:20.610
you'll see that it breaks
things up into four categories.

27
00:01:20.610 --> 00:01:23.380
Installing and
configuring the mailbox role, right.

28
00:01:23.380 --> 00:01:24.880
That's the email portion, right.

29
00:01:24.880 --> 00:01:26.610
Getting email set up.

30
00:01:26.610 --> 00:01:29.246
Installing and
configuring the client access role.

31
00:01:29.246 --> 00:01:35.770
That's getting POP3, IMAP4, the Outlook
Web App, getting those things configured,

32
00:01:35.770 --> 00:01:39.140
as well as the full Microsoft Outlook
client and some of the advanced

33
00:01:39.140 --> 00:01:43.950
functionality we get with it, seeing how
to get those implemented and put in place.

34
00:01:43.950 --> 00:01:46.751
Then we're going to move into
installing and configuring transport.

35
00:01:46.751 --> 00:01:50.277
Now, by transport we mean what
happens to our email while it moves

36
00:01:50.277 --> 00:01:51.440
across the network.

37
00:01:51.440 --> 00:01:55.879
And that might sound pretty boring, but
this is where we do things like anti-spam,

38
00:01:55.879 --> 00:01:56.700
anti-virus.

39
00:01:56.700 --> 00:01:58.270
We can do compliance or

40
00:01:58.270 --> 00:02:02.370
regulatory compliance type rules where you
do email retention or redirecting email.

41
00:02:02.370 --> 00:02:05.470
There's a lot of stuff you can do
to email while it's in transit.

42
00:02:05.470 --> 00:02:07.590
It might be really complex things or
really simple,

43
00:02:07.590 --> 00:02:11.250
like sticking a footer on the bottom
that says, this is a private email,

44
00:02:11.250 --> 00:02:13.500
please do not disclose it,
or something of that nature.

45
00:02:13.500 --> 00:02:14.880
There's a lot we can do there.

46
00:02:14.880 --> 00:02:17.880
We'll see how to manage our
message queues, and so on.

47
00:02:17.880 --> 00:02:21.120
And then we've got designing and
managing an Exchange infrastructure.

48
00:02:21.120 --> 00:02:24.560
When you start to build this out,
you'll find that small environments

49
00:02:24.560 --> 00:02:27.320
have very different needs
from large environments.

50
00:02:27.320 --> 00:02:30.940
If you just have one Exchange
administrator and 20 mailboxes,

51
00:02:30.940 --> 00:02:33.900
you can have a really straightforward and
simple Exchange deployment.

52
00:02:33.900 --> 00:02:35.910
But if you have 50,000 users and

53
00:02:35.910 --> 00:02:40.080
ten Exchange administrators, well, now
things get a lot more complex and so we'll

54
00:02:40.080 --> 00:02:44.040
look at some of the functionality that's
built into Exchange that supports that.

55
00:02:44.040 --> 00:02:44.970
So, all in all,

56
00:02:44.970 --> 00:02:47.980
it's gonna be a really good series
covering all the information you need.

57
00:02:47.980 --> 00:02:49.400
If you wanna get certified, great.

58
00:02:49.400 --> 00:02:51.240
We're gonna cover all the objectives.

59
00:02:51.240 --> 00:02:54.412
If you're not interested in getting
certified, that's fine too.

60
00:02:54.412 --> 00:02:56.980
We're gonna show you what you
need to know about Exchange to

61
00:02:56.980 --> 00:02:59.750
get it deployed in your environment,
and to be able to take

62
00:02:59.750 --> 00:03:02.990
advantage of the really cool features
that are new in Exchange 2013.

63
00:03:02.990 --> 00:03:06.960
So, if that sounds interesting to you,
then you're in the right place.

64
00:03:06.960 --> 00:03:10.456
Stay tuned, we've got
Microsoft Exchange 2013 coming up next.

65
00:03:10.456 --> 00:03:17.249
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to Microsoft Exchange 2013. He discusses the differences between the Standard and Enterprise editions of Exchange, and wraps up by discussing how Exchange licensing is handled.
episodes.title: Introduction to Exchange 2013

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses the server roles available in Exchange 2013. He begins by discussing the roles found in Exchange 2010 and earlier, and then wraps up by explaining the mail flow in Exchange 2013 along with how each role interacts.
episodes.title: Exchange Server Roles

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses the steps necessary to prepare your Active Directory prior to installing Exchange 2013. He also discusses some of the different administrative roles that may need to be involved in getting prepared for an Exchange deployment.
episodes.title: Preparing the Active Directory

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates installing Exchange 2013 on a Windows Server 2012 R2 system. He discusses the prerequisites and then walks the viewers through a Mailbox and Client Access server install.
episodes.title: Installing Exchange Server 2013

episodes.description: In this episode Don introduces the viewers to the Exchange 2013 mailbox database. He discusses the files that makeup a mailbox database and walks us through how to create our own databases.
episodes.title: Mailbox Databases

episodes.description: In this episode, Don continues discussing mailbox databases. He begins by demonstrating how to move mailbox databases to alternate locations. He then discusses tuning the file system to ensure that the database operates at optimal efficiency.
episodes.title: Mailbox Databases Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don introduces the viewers to the Exchange 2013 public folder functionality. He discusses how to create and configure public folders. He wraps up the episode by demonstrating how to set permissions and load data into a public folder.
episodes.title: Public Folders

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how Microsoft Exchange assembles a Global Address List. He also shows how to create custom address lists suitable for creating filtered address books for the end users. He ends the show describing the offline address book process.
episodes.title: Address Books

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates the various recipient types found in Exchange. He walks the viewers through creating standard user mailboxes, and then moves on to more specialized recipients like resource mailboxes and shared mailboxes.
episodes.title: Recipients

episodes.description: This episode is the exciting conclusion to Exchange recipients. In this episode, Don moves on to more specialized recipients like resource mailboxes and shared mailboxes.
episodes.title: Recipients Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don describes the various types of distribution groups found in Exchange 2013. He demonstrates how to create and manage the groups, as well as when one group type would be preferred over another based on a client's needs.
episodes.title: Distribution Groups

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates the various methods for users to delegate access to their Exchange email. He covers Send As, Send on Behalf of, and Full Access delegations as well as which should be used in what scenarios.
episodes.title: Mailbox Delegation

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to configured "accepted domains" in Exchange 2013. This is a critical piece to ensure mail flows properly in a new Exchange install. He ends the episode by configuring Address Policies to apply the new domain suffix to new and existing user accounts.
episodes.title: Email Address Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the various methods that a client can use to connect to Exchange 2013. He demonstrates MAPI, Outlook Anywhere, ActiveSync, POP3, IMAP4 and SMTP. He also gives some pointers as to when one connectivity method is preferred over another.
episodes.title: Client Connectivity

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the Autodiscover service in Exchange 2013. He demonstrates how Microsoft Outlook clients can automatically configure themselves to access an Exchange server. He also explains the steps needed to support clients outside of your local network.
episodes.title: Autodiscover

episodes.description: This episode is the exciting conclusion to the Autodiscover episode. In the last episode, Don demonstrated LAN connectivity. In this episode, he demonstrates configuring Autodiscover for external clients. He ends the episode demonstrating the MailTips feature in Exchange 2013.
episodes.title: Autodiscover Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don takes the viewers into the world of bring your own device (BYOD) clients. He demonstrates the mobile device management features found in Exchange 2013. He ends the episode by applying a mobile security policy to an Android device.
episodes.title: Mobile Access

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to configure high availability for Client Access Servers in Exchange 2013. He walks the viewers through the process of installing and configuring the Network Load Balancing feature found in Windows 2012.
episodes.title: Network Load Balancing

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains the default send and receive connectors present in Exchange 2013. He then demonstrates how to create custom connectors, and some of the various scenarios where that would be necessary.
episodes.title: Send/Receive Connectors

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how Transport Rules function in Exchange 2013. He then demonstrates how to configure Transport Rules to achieve common scenarios like appending a legal disclaimer to all emails.
episodes.title: Transport Rules

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explores the message queues maintained by the Hub Transport Service found on Exchange Mailbox servers. He demonstrates how the queues work as well as troubleshooting and monitoring techniques.
episodes.title: Message Queues

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains Microsoft Exchange Edge Transport Servers and their purpose. He then walks the viewers through the prerequisites and installation process.
episodes.title: Installing Edge Servers

episodes.description: This episode is the exciting conclusion to the Installing Edge Servers episode. Now that the server is installed, Don demonstrates how to connect the server to the internal network and verify replication between the systems.
episodes.title: Installing Edge Servers Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don walks the viewers through the available transport agents found on an Edge Transport server. He demonstrates several scenarios where transport rules can be applied to improve email security. He ends the episode by showing how to replicate the rules between Edge servers.
episodes.title: Configuring Rules

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses some of the different methods available for monitoring replication health in Exchange 2013. He begins by demonstrating how to use the PowerShell to query Database Copy status and Database Availability Group health. He then demonstrates using several counters in the Windows Performance Monitor to record performance trends over longer periods of time.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Maintenance

episodes.description: In this episode, Don discusses some of the various methods for monitoring the performance and health of Exchange 2013 Mailbox servers and Client Access Servers. He discusses several Performance Monitor counters and highlights how each can be used to monitor different aspects of Exchange performance. He wraps up the show by discussing the Exchange Best Practices Analyzer (BPA).
episodes.title: Monitoring and Maintenance Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don wraps up demonstrating how to monitor Microsoft Exchange 2013 Client Access and Mailbox servers. He shifts from the standard performance counters covered in part 2, to “customer experience” counters that better reflect the end-user experience when sending and receiving email. He discusses ways to detect resource limitations in OWA, Outlook and SMTP.
episodes.title: Monitoring and Maintenance Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to configure Database Availability Groups in Exchange 2013. He discusses the prerequisites and walks the viewers through the setup process.
episodes.title: Database Availability Groups

episodes.description: This episode is the exciting conclusion to Database Availability Groups. Now that the servers are configured, Don continues on with the configuration to create multiple database copies. He ends the episode by demonstrating how the database can failover during a failure.
episodes.title: Database Availability Groups Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to properly backup and restore an Exchange mailbox database. He explains various backup strategies as well as some third party software that may be more appropriate in some situations.
episodes.title: Mailbox Database Restore

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates creating a Dial Tone database in Exchange. This is the quickest way to get a failed Mailbox Server online after a failure, but requires proper planning and execution.
episodes.title: Dial Tone Restore

episodes.description: In this episode, Don explains how to restore a Public Folder environment in Exchange 2013. He describes how to restore the entire Public Folder mailbox, as well as how to restore individual folders. Finally, he demonstrates the process.
episodes.title: Public Folder Restore

episodes.description: In this episode, Don demonstrates how to use Microsoft Exchange Recovery Databases to restore a single user's mailbox. While complex, the process is preferable to a full restore as it does not disturb other user's mailboxes.
episodes.title: Single Mailbox Recovery
